title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of this Act. The findings section follows. Congress finds that infertility is recognized as a disease by the World Health Organization and is considered an emerging public health priority by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Approximately 3,000,000 individuals have infertility according to the CDC. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 states having laws requiring comprehensive coverage. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is sparse and inconsistent at the State level, with only 8 States having laws requiring comprehensive coverage. Even in States with coverage mandates, in vitro fertilization is limited, covered by only 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans and 11 percent of small employer-sponsored health plans. Out-of-pocket expenses for in vitro fertilization are significant, with only 19% of large employer-sponsored health plans and 11% of small employer-sponsored health plans covering the treatment. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR CERTAIN INFERTILITY TREATMENTS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section providing a credit for certain infertility treatments. A credit of 50% of qualified infertility treatment expenses paid or incurred during the taxable year is allowed for eligible individuals, with a limit of $13,360 for all taxable years. The credit for infertility treatment expenses is limited to $13,360 for eligible individuals, with a reduction based on adjusted gross income. The credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on adjusted gross income, with the reduction calculated as a ratio of the taxpayer's income exceeding $150,000 to $40,000. Adjusted gross income is determined without considering specific sections. No double benefit is allowed for the credit. Adjusted gross income is calculated without considering certain sections for the purposes of determining the credit for infertility treatment expenses. No double benefit is allowed for expenses that have already received a deduction or credit under other provisions of the tax code. Additionally, the credit is not allowed for expenses that have been reimbursed by Federal, State, or local funds. No credit is allowed for expenses reimbursed by Federal, State, or local programs or insurance policies. The credit allowed for expenses under subsection (a) is limited based on the amount of tax for the taxable year, not exceeding the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the sum of other allowable credits. The credit allowed under subsection (a) is limited by the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus other allowable credits. Unused credit can be carried forward in certain cases. If the credit allowable under subsection (a) exceeds the limitation imposed for the taxable year, the excess can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. The excess credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year, with a limitation of no carryforward beyond the 5th taxable year after the credit arose. No credit can be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after it arose, with credits treated on a first-in first-out basis. Qualified infertility treatment expenses include in vitro fertilization treatment by a licensed physician. The term 'qualified infertility treatment expenses' refers to payments for in vitro fertilization treatment administered by a licensed medical practitioner for infertility diagnosed by a US licensed physician. Treatment expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical procedures that may cause infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of diagnosis. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before procedures that may result in infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of diagnosis. The term 'infertility' refers to the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, including iatrogenic infertility from medical treatments. It does not include infertility or sterilization resulting from a procedure designed for such purpose. An eligible individual is someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician in the United States. For tax purposes, an eligible individual is someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician in the United States. Married taxpayers must file joint returns, and there are adjustments for inflation in dollar limitations. Adjustments for inflation in dollar limitations apply for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The dollar amount in subsection (b)(1) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. "Increase in dollar amount for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002, under section 1(f)(3) by substituting 'calendar year 2011' for 'calendar year 1992'. Amounts not multiples of $10 are rounded to the nearest multiple. Income limitation adjustment for taxable years after December 31, 2002, by multiplying the dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) by a certain dollar amount." "Income limitation adjustment for taxable years after December 31, 2002, involves increasing the dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) by a cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. Any resulting amount not a multiple of $10 is rounded to the nearest." The text discusses adjusting dollar amounts for taxable years after December 31, 2002, by increasing the amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) for the calendar year. Any resulting amount not a multiple of $10 is rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Additionally, there are conforming amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 23A allows for a credit for certain infertility treatments. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to include references to section 23A. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding references to sections 23A and 25D. Effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2011.
